results.notes: This is a common bolete during the summer months on the gulf coast from early June to October, depending on rain. I find them growing in the grass around oaks, mostly live oaks. It has stuffed white pores when young that turn yellow as they open and then eventually turn olive yellow/green with age. They do get rather large with some cap measuring over nine inches. The inside and outside of this mushroom do not stain at all. Cap color varies from a dark brown to a light brown when exposed to the sun. The stipe sometimes has reticulation that will cover the entire stipe and sometimes it can be faint and hard to see.

DNA sequencing results & discussion (posted on 4-Jan-24):
A full-length nrITS sequence was obtained by Steve Russell from this material via nanopore sequencing. The RiC score is 196.
A BLASTn of this sequence matches 4 unnamed GenBank accessions with 99.3-100% similarity. Two of these accessions are derived from collections made by NJMA and Sigrid Jacob in the NJ Pine Barnens (MW582886 and MT248992.2, respectively); the other two accessions came from collections made in WI (HQ285407) and FL (OP163290). Following these, the % similarity drops to 95.4-98.3% with accessions mostly labeled as “Tricholoma portentosum”.
In the 2022 Tricholoma study by MycoQuebec, RÉPERTOIRE DES TRICHOLOMES DU QUÉBEC, T. portentosum is shown to be a member of sect. Tricholoma.1 A detailed phylogenetic tree of sect. Tricholoma is presented on p. 19 of this study. Therein, T. portentosum, a European species neotypified by a collection from Denmark (accession #LT000035), is shown to occur in North America, a well, along with its cryptic close relative labeled as “portentosum-2”. This “second portentosum”, likely an undescribed taxon, is known so far only from eastern and western Canada.
The present species is likely to be T. niveipes, based on the original description by Peck and that of Bessette et al.2,3. In the field it can be discerned from T. portentosum in “lacking yellow coloration in its cap, gills and stalk” and its preference to occur in the pinelands habitat along the outer Atlantic coastal plain.3
The BLASTn results suggest a close kinship to T. portentosum, and the attached “single click” ML-based ITS tree – heavily modeled after the MycoQuebec ITS tree on p. 19 of the Tricholoma study and rendered in phylogeny.fr – lends further support to this phylogenetic placement. The annotated portentosum-niveipes clade is shown to have a very high statistical support.
References:
1 https://blog.mycoquebec.org/...
2 https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/...
3 Besette et al., Tricholomas of North America: p. 112-113

results.notes:
5-22 mm. In wash after heavy rains from tropical storm Fiona under sea grape (Coccoloba uvifera) and Coccoloba microstachya. Found within meters of the beach in coastal xerophytic forest, basidiomata were exposed after rains washed away the leaf litter/topsoil (hypogeous). Truffles were mostly half-buried, many appear to have animal herbivory, from small bites to examples that were almost fully consumed, leaving just a small bit of exposed gleba and the attached base. Hermit crabs were conspicuously present in the area with the foraged truffles, as well as other crab species such as blue land crab and red backed land crabs. I collected 6 hermit crabs in the immediate area of the consumed truffles which I housed overnight to collect their droppings, and was able to confirm the presence of fungal spores which correspond to those of the collection. Fresh basidiomes are pale, becoming more brown upon handling/drying. Odor and taste distinctly reminiscent of raw artichoke. Gleba is dry and compact chalk-like in the most mature specimens but never becoming a loose powder. Spores in the 10-15 um range, thick walled, appearing smooth but some with a subtle pustulate or minutely undulating outline that is barely perceptible in LM but might imply texture if viewed under SEM. Inamyloid, appearing very minutely asperulate in Meltzer’s, but again barely if at all perceptible. Sent: Javier 9/22; Matt 12/22

—

results.notes: Growing in an acorn cap
These are a common find during the summer months. I find them growing under live oaks in sandy soil. The latex is sticky and white.

When I first saw this robust fruit body (at a meeting of the Wyoming Valley Mushroom Club) my first impression was A. spreta. But, even if this apparently exannulate stipe once had a ring that dropped off, the large membranous basal volva points away from spreta.
Globose/subglobose spores confirm this is not spreta, and support a proposal of section Vaginatae.
Basal limbus internus present.
Stipe context slightly darkened when fruit body was sectioned.
Spores not amyloid; globose/subglobose.
Photos taken at least 12 hours after this had been collected and handled by several different people.

Ring delicate and lost almost immediately. Stipe pale yellow, with unattached gills that are very clustered. Found in lawn near hardwoods, cap was once yellow but was out in rain and may have lost color. No distinctive smell or taste.

I was in a hurry to be on time for a mushroom club meeting when I stopped at this convenient spot along the way. I grabbed a few of these from a lawn; growing under Norway spruce, no oak or any other hardwood close enough to make a difference. My first thought was “Lanmaoa.” But, upon inspection, several factors seem to point toward B. bicolor: internal context yellow throughout (inside cap a bit brighter/paler); slow faint staining of sliced context; blue bruising on pores not becoming reddish brown; the particular feel of the way the knife blade passes through the fruit body.
I tested the spores for a possible amyloid reaction (bicoloroides?). Spores not amyloid (at very least not strongly so). Also, spores too short for bicoloroides.
Photos taken at least 12 hours after these were harvested.

results.notes: This mushroom was collected by one of our members. At first, I thought it was a Gymnopilus but she said it was collected on duff and had no ring. I then thought it was maybe a Gymnopus but it was too big and tough. I took it home and put it on the table with the other collections. When I looked at the spores, I was in for a big surprise. Typical Entoloma spores. In searching for this mushroom in T. Baroni’s book , I came across Rhodophana nitella but this mushroom was too big, without striations on the cap. I found Rhodophana listed on the California mycoweb and they mentioned Clitopilus nuciolens as bigger without striations on the cap. The cap was tawny, brownish yellow 4cm (after 2 days) smooth without striations. Stipe was 10 cm (after 2 days) gills seemed to be ragged with some shorter lamellae. I hope one of our members who was at the foray, has a fresher photo.

A group of several basidiomata growing in pitch pine woods along a narrow trail. Originally found by members of the Philadelphia club whom I happened to bump into while hiking. It was found about 10 yards away from obs 503850 that may or may not be the same species.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 6-Jan-24):
This collection was sequenced by Steve Russell (ONT-nanopore). The derived full-length ITS sequence of 602 nucleotides (bps) has a RiC score of 91.
A BLASTn search of this sequence gave a sizable mixture of accessions labeled as “Tricholoma argenteum”, “Tricholoma subacutum” and “Tricholoma virgatum” in the 97-100% similarity range. The two top hits at 99.8-100% similarity, accessions KJ705253 and MW627990, are “T. argenteum” associated with the 2022 MycoQuebec (MQ) Tricholoma study, RÉPERTOIRE DES TRICHOLOMES DU QUÉBEC.1 The three aforementioned species form a tightly knit and cluster in the phylogenetic tree of sect. Tricholoma on p. 19 of the study. The ITS sequence of the European neotype of T. virgatum (LT000197) is 98.9% similar to the present sequence.
Using relevant accessions from the MQ study, I built a smaller “single-click” ML-based tree in phylogeny.fr and posted it here as Fig. 1. The tree also includes the type accession of T. argenteum, which unfortunately lacks the ITS1 sublocus. Fig. 1 has a very similar topology for the “argenetum/subacutum/virgatum” clade. As a matter of fact, the accessions of T. argenteum and T. virgatum stand out as well-defined subclades with high statistical support, while the accessions of T. subacutum form a less resolved backbone of the overall topology (the MQ study also states on p. 28 that their accessions of T. subacutum do not form a monophyletic clade within this 3-species cluster). Since MO503851 clusters together with the type collection of T. argenteum, IMO it’s the best ID for this NJ voucher.
For more info about T. argenteum, T. subacutum and other related gray-capped taxa in sect. Tricholoma, see the MQ study — Google Translate does a decent job for those who don’t speak/understand French.
Reference:
1 https://blog.mycoquebec.org/...

A group of several basidiomata growing in pitch pine woods along a narrow trail; some white pine and hardwoods mixed in nearby. Originally collected by members of the Philadelphia club whom I happened to bump into while hiking on the same trail where Tricholoma argenteum of obs 503850 & obs 503851 were found.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 20-Jan-24; edited on 21-Jan-24):
A full-length nrITS sequence of 645 base pairs (bps) was obtained by Steve Russell from this collection (ONT-nanopore sequencing). The RiC score is 252.
The standard BLASTn-100 search of this sequence gave GenBank accession ON179783 labeled as “Cystodermella granulosa” as the sole matching hit at 100% similarity. This accession had been derived from a collection made in Massachusetts. Following this hit the % similarity droped to ~90% with various Cystoderma accessions. There were no accessions labeled as “Cystodermella” in this hit list. As a BLASTn-500 search still didn’t produce any hits labeled as “Cystodermella”, it became evident that the matching accession incorrectly identified by the FunDiS team as “Cystodermella granulosa” was best identified as an undescribed taxon of Cystoderma.
A careful selection process of Cystoderma and Cystodermella accessions for a ML-based phylogenetic tree was guided by two publications on these genera by Saar et al. (2009) and Li et al.(2022).1,2 The resultant “single click” tree posted in this observation as Fig. 1 was rendered in phylogeny.fr, with bona fide accessions of Cystodermella lifted from Saar et al. and serving as the outgroup. As can be seen from the tree the present species firmly nests within the genus Cystoderma (monophyletic, 1.0 PP) and clearly represents a unique NA phylogenetic lineage most closely related to Cystoderma lignicola (with 0.85 PP), a species currently known only from southeast Asia. The ML-tree features 17 Cystoderma species, including that of MO503858, with many supported by type sequences identified in GenBank and the two listed publications.
It is possible that this novel North American species of Cystoderma is widespread and common in the eastern part of the continent, but has hitherto gone unnoticed by both amateur and professional mycologists because of its similar appearance in the field to a number of published species in this genus, as well as those of Cystodermella.3 Lack of comprehensive DNA-driven studies of these genera in the Americas is a compounding factor, too.
References:
1 Saar et al., “The phylogeny and taxonomy of genera Cystoderma and Cystodermella (Agaricales) based on nuclear ITS and LSU sequences”, Mycol. Progress 8: 59–73 (2009); downloadable from https://www.researchgate.net/...
2 Li et al., “A review of Cystoderma (Agaricales/Basidiomycota) from China with four new species and two new records”, Mycology 13(3): 163–176 (2022); downloadable from https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35938081/
3 https://www.mushroomexpert.com/cystoderma.html

results.notes:
Growing on mossy, well-decayed wood in hemlock forest. CAP 1.5-4.5 cm, umbonate, dull yellow with a light chestnut-brown center, viscid, waxy. FLESH yellow, watery, slightly translucent. GILLS adnate, close, waxy. STEM 2-5 mm X 3-7 cm, dry, fibrillose, lemon-yellow at apex, buff below to slightly greenish at base, hollow at center with distinctly greenish flesh below apex. PARTIAL VEIL remnants present when very young, cottony. SPORE PRINT dull brown. MICROSCOPIC CHARACTERISTICS Cystidia flask-shaped, ornamented. Cap cuticle filamentous. Spores oval, without germ pore.

CORRECTION: Germ pore present.
